title: How to Make Biscuits with Self Rising Flour

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and get out a baking sheet.
steps.description: Turn the oven on to 425 °F (218 °C). Get out a baking sheet and set it next to your work surface.

steps.headline: Measure the flour and cut the butter into pieces.
steps.description: Measure 2 cups (227 g) of unbleached self-rising flour into a mixing bowl. Get out 1/4 cup (57 g) of cold butter and cut it into three or four pieces. If you're using shortening, just scoop the shortening out of the container.

steps.headline: Rub the butter into the flour.
steps.description: Place the pieces of butter or the shortening into the flour. Use your fingertips to combine the butter with the flour. Keep rubbing in the butter until it breaks down into small lumps. The mixture should be crumbly.

steps.headline: Stir in cold buttermilk.
steps.description: Pour 2/3 cup (157 ml) of buttermilk or cold milk into the flour mixture. Use a spoon to stir the liquid into the flour until the dough is just combined. If there's still a lot of dry mixture, you can add up to 2 extra tablespoons (30 ml) of buttermilk. Avoid adding too much buttermilk or the biscuits will become gluey and difficult to roll out.

steps.headline: Roll the dough out on a floured surface.
steps.description: Sprinkle flour over your work surface and scoop the dough onto it. Sprinkle the dough itself with a little flour and use a rolling pin to roll it into a 5 x 8-inch (12 x 20-cm) rectangle, if you'd like square biscuits. You could also roll the dough into a large circle that's between 1/2-inch and 3/4-inch (12-mm and 19-mm) thick, if you'd like to use a circular biscuit cutter.

steps.headline: Cut the biscuits.
steps.description: If you're making square biscuits, use a sharp knife to cut the rectangle into 12 evenly sized squares. If you're making circular biscuits, take a 2-inch (5-cm) cutter and dip it in flour. Cut out as many biscuits as you can from the rolled dough. Lift away the biscuits and roll the scraps into a dough ball that you can roll out again. Cut out as many biscuits as you can. If you're cutting circular biscuits, you should get about 12 once you've re-rolled the scraps. Avoid rolling the scraps more than once or you'll get tough biscuits.

steps.headline: Arrange the biscuits on the baking sheet.
steps.description: Place the 12 circular or square biscuits on the baking sheet next to your work surface. Leave at least 1-inch (2.5 cm) of space between each biscuit.

steps.headline: Bake the buttermilk biscuits for 10 to 14 minutes.
steps.description: Put the sheet of biscuits in the preheated oven and bake the biscuits until they're a pale golden brown color. This should take 10 to 14 minutes.

steps.headline: Serve the biscuits.
steps.description: Remove the hot biscuits from the oven and serve them immediately. Biscuits are best served the day they're made, but you can store leftover biscuits in an airtight container. Store them at room temperature for a day or two.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and prepare a baking sheet.
steps.description: Turn on the oven to 450 °F (232 °C). Get out a baking sheet and lightly rub a little shortening over it. You could also lay a sheet of parchment paper or a silicone baking mat on the sheet instead of greasing it.

steps.headline: Whisk the self-rising flour with the salt.
steps.description: Measure 2 1/4 cups (285 g) of self-rising flour into a mixing bowl and add a pinch of kosher salt. Whisk the flour to distribute the salt.

steps.headline: Rub the butter into the flour.
steps.description: Cut 1/4 cup (57 g) of cold unsalted butter into four pieces. Add the pieces to the flour and rub the butter into the flour with your fingertips until they're just small lumps. The flour mixture should feel crumbly like wet sand.

steps.headline: Stir the buttermilk into the flour mixture.
steps.description: Pour 1 cup plus 1 tablespoon (255 ml) of buttermilk into the bowl. Use a spoon to combine the buttermilk with the flour mixture. Stop mixing as soon as the liquid is incorporated and there isn't any dry flour mixture in the bowl. The dough will be very thick and too sticky to handle.

steps.headline: Scoop the dough onto the baking sheet.
steps.description: Take a 1/4 cup (32 g) measuring cup and use it to scoop the dough onto the baking sheet. Leave a couple of inches (5 cm) of space between each portion of dough since they'll spread as they bake. Don't worry about smoothing, shaping, or forming these biscuits. Drop biscuits are known for their craggy free-form shapes.

steps.headline: Bake the biscuits for 12 to 14 minutes.
steps.description: Put the sheet of biscuits in the preheated oven. Bake them until the tops turn golden brown and then remove them from the oven. Serve the biscuits while they're still warm. Biscuits are best on the day they're made, but you can store them in an airtight container at room temperature for a day or two.

steps.headline: Include sugar and vanilla to make sweet biscuits.
steps.description: If you want to make tender, sweet biscuits to use for dessert or strawberry shortcake, stir 3 tablespoons (37.5 g) of sugar into the flour of your recipe. You can also stir 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla into the buttermilk or milk.

steps.headline: Stir in spices and cheese to make savory biscuits.
steps.description: Add 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of dried mustard and one pinch of cayenne pepper to the self-rising flour of your recipe. After you rub the butter in, stir 1 cup (100 g) of shredded cheddar cheese into the mixture. Do this before you add the buttermilk or milk.

steps.headline: Create high-protein yogurt biscuits.
steps.description: Combine equal parts of self-rising flour with plain, whole-milk Greek yogurt until you get a shaggy dough. Scoop the dough onto the baking sheet so you get about nine biscuits. Bake the biscuits at 400 °F (204 °C) for 15 to 20 minutes. You can also stir optional mix-ins to these biscuits. Try stirring in shredded cheese, herbs, crumbled bacon, or sun-dried tomatoes.

text: Making Buttermilk Biscuits Preheat the oven and get out a baking sheet. Turn the oven on to 425 °F (218 °C). Get out a baking sheet and set it next to your work surface. Measure the flour and cut the butter into pieces. Measure 2 cups (227 g) of unbleached self-rising flour into a mixing bowl. Get out 1/4 cup (57 g) of cold butter and cut it into three or four pieces. If you're using shortening, just scoop the shortening out of the container. Rub the butter into the flour. Place the pieces of butter or the shortening into the flour. Use your fingertips to combine the butter with the flour. Keep rubbing in the butter until it breaks down into small lumps. The mixture should be crumbly. Stir in cold buttermilk. Pour 2/3 cup (157 ml) of buttermilk or cold milk into the flour mixture. Use a spoon to stir the liquid into the flour until the dough is just combined. If there's still a lot of dry mixture, you can add up to 2 extra tablespoons (30 ml) of buttermilk. Avoid adding too much buttermilk or the biscuits will become gluey and difficult to roll out. Roll the dough out on a floured surface. Sprinkle flour over your work surface and scoop the dough onto it. Sprinkle the dough itself with a little flour and use a rolling pin to roll it into a 5 x 8-inch (12 x 20-cm) rectangle, if you'd like square biscuits. You could also roll the dough into a large circle that's between 1/2-inch and 3/4-inch (12-mm and 19-mm) thick, if you'd like to use a circular biscuit cutter. Cut the biscuits. If you're making square biscuits, use a sharp knife to cut the rectangle into 12 evenly sized squares. If you're making circular biscuits, take a 2-inch (5-cm) cutter and dip it in flour. Cut out as many biscuits as you can from the rolled dough. Lift away the biscuits and roll the scraps into a dough ball that you can roll out again. Cut out as many biscuits as you can. If you're cutting circular biscuits, you should get about 12 once you've re-rolled the scraps. Avoid rolling the scraps more than once or you'll get tough biscuits. Arrange the biscuits on the baking sheet. Place the 12 circular or square biscuits on the baking sheet next to your work surface. Leave at least 1-inch (2.5 cm) of space between each biscuit. Bake the buttermilk biscuits for 10 to 14 minutes. Put the sheet of biscuits in the preheated oven and bake the biscuits until they're a pale golden brown color. This should take 10 to 14 minutes. Serve the biscuits. Remove the hot biscuits from the oven and serve them immediately. Biscuits are best served the day they're made, but you can store leftover biscuits in an airtight container. Store them at room temperature for a day or two. Making Drop Biscuits Preheat the oven and prepare a baking sheet. Turn on the oven to 450 °F (232 °C). Get out a baking sheet and lightly rub a little shortening over it. You could also lay a sheet of parchment paper or a silicone baking mat on the sheet instead of greasing it. Whisk the self-rising flour with the salt. Measure 2 1/4 cups (285 g) of self-rising flour into a mixing bowl and add a pinch of kosher salt. Whisk the flour to distribute the salt. Rub the butter into the flour. Cut 1/4 cup (57 g) of cold unsalted butter into four pieces. Add the pieces to the flour and rub the butter into the flour with your fingertips until they're just small lumps. The flour mixture should feel crumbly like wet sand. Stir the buttermilk into the flour mixture. Pour 1 cup plus 1 tablespoon (255 ml) of buttermilk into the bowl. Use a spoon to combine the buttermilk with the flour mixture. Stop mixing as soon as the liquid is incorporated and there isn't any dry flour mixture in the bowl. The dough will be very thick and too sticky to handle. Scoop the dough onto the baking sheet. Take a 1/4 cup (32 g) measuring cup and use it to scoop the dough onto the baking sheet. Leave a couple of inches (5 cm) of space between each portion of dough since they'll spread as they bake. Don't worry about smoothing, shaping, or forming these biscuits. Drop biscuits are known for their craggy free-form shapes. Bake the biscuits for 12 to 14 minutes. Put the sheet of biscuits in the preheated oven. Bake them until the tops turn golden brown and then remove them from the oven. Serve the biscuits while they're still warm. Biscuits are best on the day they're made, but you can store them in an airtight container at room temperature for a day or two. Trying Variations Include sugar and vanilla to make sweet biscuits. If you want to make tender, sweet biscuits to use for dessert or strawberry shortcake, stir 3 tablespoons (37.5 g) of sugar into the flour of your recipe. You can also stir 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla into the buttermilk or milk. Stir in spices and cheese to make savory biscuits. Add 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of dried mustard and one pinch of cayenne pepper to the self-rising flour of your recipe. After you rub the butter in, stir 1 cup (100 g) of shredded cheddar cheese into the mixture. Do this before you add the buttermilk or milk. Create high-protein yogurt biscuits. Combine equal parts of self-rising flour with plain, whole-milk Greek yogurt until you get a shaggy dough. Scoop the dough onto the baking sheet so you get about nine biscuits. Bake the biscuits at 400 °F (204 °C) for 15 to 20 minutes. You can also stir optional mix-ins to these biscuits. Try stirring in shredded cheese, herbs, crumbled bacon, or sun-dried tomatoes.

Turn the oven on to 425 °F (218 °C).
Get out a baking sheet and set it next to your work surface.
Measure the flour and cut the butter into pieces.
Measure 2 cups (227 g) of unbleached self-rising flour into a mixing bowl.
Get out 1/4 cup (57 g) of cold butter and cut it into three or four pieces.
If you're using shortening, just scoop the shortening out of the container.
Rub the butter into the flour.
Place the pieces of butter or the shortening into the flour.
Use your fingertips to combine the butter with the flour.
Keep rubbing in the butter until it breaks down into small lumps.
The mixture should be crumbly.
Stir in cold buttermilk.
Pour 2/3 cup (157 ml) of buttermilk or cold milk into the flour mixture.
Use a spoon to stir the liquid into the flour until the dough is just combined.
If there's still a lot of dry mixture, you can add up to 2 extra tablespoons (30 ml) of buttermilk.
Avoid adding too much buttermilk or the biscuits will become gluey and difficult to roll out.
Roll the dough out on a floured surface.
Sprinkle flour over your work surface and scoop the dough onto it.
Sprinkle the dough itself with a little flour and use a rolling pin to roll it into a 5 x 8-inch (12 x 20-cm) rectangle, if you'd like square biscuits.
You could also roll the dough into a large circle that's between 1/2-inch and 3/4-inch (12-mm and 19-mm) thick, if you'd like to use a circular biscuit cutter.
Cut the biscuits.
If you're making square biscuits, use a sharp knife to cut the rectangle into 12 evenly sized squares.
If you're making circular biscuits, take a 2-inch (5-cm) cutter and dip it in flour.
Cut out as many biscuits as you can from the rolled dough.
Lift away the biscuits and roll the scraps into a dough ball that you can roll out again.
Cut out as many biscuits as you can.
If you're cutting circular biscuits, you should get about 12 once you've re-rolled the scraps.
Avoid rolling the scraps more than once or you'll get tough biscuits.
Arrange the biscuits on the baking sheet.
Place the 12 circular or square biscuits on the baking sheet next to your work surface.
Leave at least 1-inch (2.5 cm) of space between each biscuit.
Bake the buttermilk biscuits for 10 to 14 minutes.
Put the sheet of biscuits in the preheated oven and bake the biscuits until they're a pale golden brown color.
This should take 10 to 14 minutes.
Serve the biscuits.
Remove the hot biscuits from the oven and serve them immediately.
Biscuits are best served the day they're made, but you can store leftover biscuits in an airtight container.
Store them at room temperature for a day or two.
Making Drop Biscuits Preheat the oven and prepare a baking sheet.
Turn on the oven to 450 °F (232 °C).
Get out a baking sheet and lightly rub a little shortening over it.
You could also lay a sheet of parchment paper or a silicone baking mat on the sheet instead of greasing it.
Whisk the self-rising flour with the salt.
Measure 2 1/4 cups (285 g) of self-rising flour into a mixing bowl and add a pinch of kosher salt.
Whisk the flour to distribute the salt.
Rub the butter into the flour.
Cut 1/4 cup (57 g) of cold unsalted butter into four pieces.
Add the pieces to the flour and rub the butter into the flour with your fingertips until they're just small lumps.
The flour mixture should feel crumbly like wet sand.
Stir the buttermilk into the flour mixture.
Pour 1 cup plus 1 tablespoon (255 ml) of buttermilk into the bowl.
Use a spoon to combine the buttermilk with the flour mixture.
Stop mixing as soon as the liquid is incorporated and there isn't any dry flour mixture in the bowl.
The dough will be very thick and too sticky to handle.
Scoop the dough onto the baking sheet.
Take a 1/4 cup (32 g) measuring cup and use it to scoop the dough onto the baking sheet.
Leave a couple of inches (5 cm) of space between each portion of dough since they'll spread as they bake.
Don't worry about smoothing, shaping, or forming these biscuits.
Drop biscuits are known for their craggy free-form shapes.
Bake the biscuits for 12 to 14 minutes.
Put the sheet of biscuits in the preheated oven.
Bake them until the tops turn golden brown and then remove them from the oven.
Serve the biscuits while they're still warm.
Biscuits are best on the day they're made, but you can store them in an airtight container at room temperature for a day or two.
Trying Variations Include sugar and vanilla to make sweet biscuits.
If you want to make tender, sweet biscuits to use for dessert or strawberry shortcake, stir 3 tablespoons (37.5 g) of sugar into the flour of your recipe.
You can also stir 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla into the buttermilk or milk.
Stir in spices and cheese to make savory biscuits.
Add 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of dried mustard and one pinch of cayenne pepper to the self-rising flour of your recipe.
After you rub the butter in, stir 1 cup (100 g) of shredded cheddar cheese into the mixture.
Do this before you add the buttermilk or milk.
Create high-protein yogurt biscuits.
Combine equal parts of self-rising flour with plain, whole-milk Greek yogurt until you get a shaggy dough.
Scoop the dough onto the baking sheet so you get about nine biscuits.
Bake the biscuits at 400 °F (204 °C) for 15 to 20 minutes.
You can also stir optional mix-ins to these biscuits.
Try stirring in shredded cheese, herbs, crumbled bacon, or sun-dried tomatoes.
